1. Introduction 1. Introduction
This document is an Applicability Statement [RFC2026], Section 3.2 This document is an Applicability Statement [RFC2026], Section 3.2
that provides guidance in the use of the Internet's core email that provides guidance in the use of the Internet's core email
specifications, the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) specifications, the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP)
[I-D.ietf-emailcore-rfc5321bis] and the Internet Message Format (IMF) [I-D.ietf-emailcore-rfc5321bis] and the Internet Message Format (IMF)
[I-D.ietf-emailcore-rfc5322bis], and some extensions and other [I-D.ietf-emailcore-rfc5322bis], and some extensions and other
protocols that have been built on them. In order to promote protocols that have been built on them. In order to promote
interoperability amongst senders, receivers, and intermediaries, it interoperability amongst senders, receivers, and intermediaries, it

of Transport Layer Security (TLS) [RFC8446] to provide both of Transport Layer Security (TLS) [RFC8446] to provide both
confidentiality and authentication in the transmission of messages. confidentiality and authentication in the transmission of messages.

"Authentication" and "Confidentiality", and for that we will borrow "Authentication" and "Confidentiality", and for that we will borrow
directly from RFC8446. directly from RFC8446.
* Authentication is the process of establishing the identity of one * Authentication is the process of establishing the identity of one
or more of the endpoints of a communication channel. TLS only or more of the endpoints of a communication channel.
requires authentication of the server side of the communication
channel; authentication of the client side is optional.
* The term "confidentiality" describes a state where the data (i.e., * The term "confidentiality" describes a state where the data (i.e.,
the message) is transmitted in a way that it is only visible to the message) is transmitted in a way that it is only visible to
the endpoints of a communication channel. the endpoints of a communication channel.
It is not uncommon for implementers to use the term "encryption" to It is not uncommon for implementers to use the term "encryption" to
mean "confidentiality", but this is not quite correct. Rather, mean "confidentiality", but this is not quite correct. Rather,
encryption using TLS is the current method by which confidentiality encryption using TLS is the current method by which confidentiality
is achieved with SMTP, but that does not mean that future methods is achieved with SMTP, but that does not mean that future methods

6.2. Opportunistic Confidentiality 6.2. Opportunistic Confidentiality
The most common implementation of message confidentiality is what's The most common implementation of message confidentiality is what's
known as "opportunistic TLS", which is frequently referred to as known as "opportunistic TLS", which is frequently referred to as
"opportunistic encryption". With this method, a receiving server "opportunistic encryption". With this method, a receiving server
announces in its greeting that it is capable of supporting TLS announces in its greeting that it is capable of supporting TLS
encryption through the presence of the "STARTTLS" keyword. The encryption through the presence of the "STARTTLS" keyword. The
sending client then attempts to negotiate an encrypted connection, sending client then attempts to negotiate an encrypted connection,
and if successful, transmits the message in encrypted form; if and if successful, transmits the message in encrypted form; if
skipping to change at page 12, line 18 ¶ skipping to change at page 12, line 18 ¶
confidentiality without authentication, where no effort is made to confidentiality without authentication, where no effort is made to
authenticate the receiving server [RFC3207], Section 4.1. Most authenticate the receiving server [RFC3207], Section 4.1. Most
modern implementations of SMTP support this method and so the vast modern implementations of SMTP support this method and so the vast
majority of email traffic is encrypted during its time transiting majority of email traffic is encrypted during its time transiting
from the client to the server. from the client to the server.
Note that opportunistic TLS via the STARTTLS [RFC3207] extension is Note that opportunistic TLS via the STARTTLS [RFC3207] extension is
vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks. Enforced confidentiality vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks. Enforced confidentiality
(Section 6.3) can be used to mitigate these attacks. (Section 6.3) can be used to mitigate these attacks.
Also, note that while TLS provides protection while the message is in
transit, there is no guarantee that the message will be stored in
encrypted fashion at its destination. In fact, storage in plain text
should be expected! Also, in a situation where a message traverses
multiple hops through multiple SMTP servers, each intermediate server
will have access to the plain text of the message. The only way to
completely assure confidentiality so that no one server has access to
the contents of a message is to use message-level confidentiality as
described in Section 6.4.
6.3. Enforced Confidentiality, with Receiving Server Authentication 6.3. Enforced Confidentiality, with Receiving Server Authentication
Two protocols exist that move message confidentiality from Two protocols exist that move message confidentiality from
opportunistic to enforced (with conditions as noted below) - MTA-STS opportunistic to enforced (with conditions as noted below) - MTA-STS
[RFC8461] and DANE for SMTP [RFC7672]. While they differ in their [RFC8461] and DANE for SMTP [RFC7672]. While they differ in their
implementation details, receiving servers relying on either protocol implementation details, receiving servers relying on either protocol
are stating that they only accept mail if the transmission can be can state that they only accept mail if the transmission can be
encrypted with TLS, and a failure to negotiate a secure connection encrypted with TLS. Support for both protocols is increasing, but is
MUST result in the sending client refusing to transmit the message. not yet mandatory.
Support for both protocols is increasing, but is not yet mandatory.
These two protocols differ from Opportunistic TLS in that they These two protocols differ from Opportunistic TLS in that they
require receiving server authentication and there is no fallback to require receiving server authentication and there is no fallback to
sending in the clear if negotiation of an encrypted connection fails. sending in the clear if negotiation of an encrypted connection fails.
However, as noted in Section 6.2, both SMTP servers will most likely
have access to the plain text of the message, as will all SMTP
servers where multiple hops are involved. Again, only message-level
confidentiality described in Section 6.4 will prevent that lack of
confidentiality.
Note that both protocols mentioned in this section rely not only on Note that both protocols mentioned in this section rely not only on
the receiving server but also the sending client supporting the the receiving server but also the sending client supporting the
protocol intended to be used. If the sending client does not protocol intended to be used.
implement or understand the protocol requested by the receiving
server, the sending client will use Opportunistic TLS or clear-text
to transmit the message.
6.4. Message-Level Authentication 6.4. Message-Level Confidentiality
Protocols such as S/MIME [RFC8551] and OpenPGP [RFC9580] exist to
allow for message confidentiality outside of the operation of SMTP.
That is to say, using these protocols results in encryption of the
message body prior to its being submitted to the SMTP communications
channel, and decryption of the message is the responsibility of the
message recipient. There are numerous implementations of these
protocols, too many to list here. As they operate fully independent
of SMTP, they are out of scope for this document.
Header Protection for Cryptographically Protected E-mail
[I-D.ietf-lamps-header-protection] extends S/MIME such that some
message headers can be encrypted.
6.5. Confidentiality Limitations
Technologies like TLS can encrypt the entirety of a message in
transit, but SMTP servers require access to at least some message
headers in order to function. Some of the protocols listed in
Message-Level Confidentiality (Section 6.4) only cover the message
body, and none of the headers. See the Privacy Considerations in
Section 11 of Header Protection for Cryptographically Protected
E-mail [I-D.ietf-lamps-header-protection] for an extended
explanation.
6.6. Confidentiality Requirements
The vast majority of email sent on the Internet at present does not
use message-level confidentiality. It has been recognized that
Internet traffic is exposed to both active attack and passive
monitoring (see BCP61 [RFC3365], BCP200 [RFC1984]), and therefore
that message transmission over SMTP is subject to both. To mitigate
these risks, opportunistic confidentiality is now widely implemented
and used in Internet email, and some deployment and use of enforced
confidentiality is also now seen. Therefore, confidentiality (for
example, the STARTTLS extension) MUST be implemented by SMTP servers
in order to at least provide over-the-wire confidentiality during an
individual SMTP exchange. That said, there are many legacy
implementations of SMTP that are still in widespread use in both
private and Internet-connected networks. Therefore, SMTP servers
MUST be configurable to allow for receiving messages without
confidentiality between servers in order to maximize interoperation.
6.7. Message-Level Authentication
Protocols exist to allow for authentication of different identities Protocols exist to allow for authentication of different identities
associated with an email message: associated with an email message:
* SPF [RFC7208] provides a method to ensure that the sending mail * SPF [RFC7208] provides a method to ensure that the sending mail
server is authorized to originate mail from the sender's domain. server is authorized to originate mail from the sender's domain.
* DKIM [RFC6376] permits a person, role, or organization to claim * DKIM [RFC6376] permits a person, role, or organization to claim
some responsibility for an email message by associating a domain some responsibility for an email message by associating a domain
name [RFC1034] with the message, which they are authorized to use. name [RFC1034] with the message, which they are authorized to use.

[I-D.ietf-lamps-header-protection], allow for emails to be [I-D.ietf-lamps-header-protection], allow for emails to be
digitally signed, thereby providing a method to verify that an digitally signed, thereby providing a method to verify that an
email was actually sent by the entity claiming to be the sender. email was actually sent by the entity claiming to be the sender.
All of these are outside the scope of this document, as they are All of these are outside the scope of this document, as they are
outside the scope of SMTP. They deal with validating the authorized outside the scope of SMTP. They deal with validating the authorized
usage of one or more domains in an email message, and not with usage of one or more domains in an email message, and not with
establishing the identity of the receiving server. establishing the identity of the receiving server.
6.5. SMTP Authentication 6.8. SMTP Authentication
SMTP Authentication [RFC4954], which is often abbreviated as SMTP SMTP Authentication [RFC4954], which is often abbreviated as SMTP
AUTH, is an extension to SMTP. While its name might suggest that it AUTH, is an extension to SMTP. While its name might suggest that it
would be within scope for this section of the Applicability would be within scope for this section of the Applicability
Statement, nothing could be further from the truth. Statement, nothing could be further from the truth.
SMTP AUTH defines a method for a client to identify itself to a SMTP AUTH defines a method for a client to identify itself to a
Message Submission Agent (MSA) when presenting a message for Message Submission Agent (MSA) when presenting a message for
transmission, usually using ports 465 or 587 rather than the transmission, usually using ports 465 or 587 rather than the
traditional port 25. The most common implementation of SMTP AUTH is traditional port 25. The most common implementation of SMTP AUTH is
for a person to present a username and password to their mailbox for a person to present a username and password to their mailbox
provider's outbound SMTP server when configuring their MUA for provider's outbound SMTP server when configuring their MUA for
sending mail. sending mail.
SMPT AUTH MAY be used to limit unauthorized use of VRFY and EXPN SMPT AUTH MAY be used to limit unauthorized use of VRFY and EXPN
commands as described in Section 7.3 of commands as described in Section 7.3 of
[I-D.ietf-emailcore-rfc5321bis]. [I-D.ietf-emailcore-rfc5321bis].
6.6. Message-Level Confidentiality
Protocols such as S/MIME [RFC8551] and OpenPGP [RFC9580] exist to
allow for message confidentiality outside of the operation of SMTP.
That is to say, using these protocols results in encryption of the
message prior to its being submitted to the SMTP communications
channel, and decryption of the message is the responsibility of the
message recipient. There are numerous implementations of these
protocols, too many to list here. As they operate fully independent
of SMTP, they are out of scope for this document.
6.7. Confidentiality Requirements
The vast majority of email sent on the Internet at present does not
use message-level confidentiality. It has been recognized that
Internet traffic is exposed to both active attack and passive
monitoring (see BCP61 [RFC3365], BCP200 [RFC1984]), and therefore
that message transmission over SMTP is subject to both. To mitigate
these risks, opportunistic confidentiality is now widely implemented
and used in Internet email, and some deployment and use of enforced
confidentiality is also now seen. Therefore, confidentiality (for
example, the STARTTLS extension) MUST be implemented by SMTP servers
in order to at least provide over-the-wire confidentiality during an
individual SMTP exchange. That said, there are many legacy
implementations of SMTP that are still in widespread use in both
private and Internet-connected networks, and most receiving servers
implementations will be expected to be capable of receiving such
messages. Therefore, SMTP servers MUST be configurable to allow for
receiving messages without confidentiality between servers in order
to maximize interoperation.
7. Acknowledgments 7. Acknowledgments
The Emailcore group arose out of discussions on the ietf-smtp group The Emailcore group arose out of discussions on the ietf-smtp group
over changes and additions that should be made to the core email over changes and additions that should be made to the core email
protocols. It was agreed upon that it was time to create a working protocols. It was agreed upon that it was time to create a working
group that would fix many potential errors and opportunities for group that would fix many potential errors and opportunities for
misunderstandings within the RFCs. misunderstandings within the RFCs.
